author: By Rebekah Peppler
title: For Summertime Mocktails That Shine, Look to Tea
description: With its tannic qualities and endless applications, tea can add much-appreciated complexity to nonalcoholic drinks.
content: In early 2020, I developed long Covid and stopped being able to tolerate alcohol. In my experience, it was among the triggers of relapses so severe I would spend long stretches of time incapacitated with renewed symptoms of extreme fatigue, brain fog, tachycardia and more. As a food and drinks writer, this presented a particularly distressing work challenge: How could I create recipes that I couldn’t always have?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Once a Literary Snob, Chris Pavone Learned From the Experts
description: The best-selling author crossed paths with John Grisham and Pat Conroy early in his career. Here’s what they taught him.
content: Like many a newcomer in the publishing world, Chris Pavone was an avid reader of “capital-L literature” when he landed a job as a copy editor at Doubleday in the mid-1990s. This was back in the day when Rolodexes and IBM Selectrics hulked on desks and manuscripts arrived by mail in white boxes that held all the promise of a warm crumb cake from the bakery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Ivor Prickett
title: ‘Dead Cities’ Become the Flashpoint for the Fierce War in the East
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky has framed the battle in Sievierodonetsk as pivotal to the broader fight for the Donbas. Amid relentless Russian attacks, Ukraine holds on and waits for Western weapons.
content: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — Just to move about town, Ukrainian soldiers accelerate to breakneck speeds in their SUVs, screech around corners, zip into courtyards, then pile out and run for cover.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Ranan Lurie, Political Cartoonist With a Global Pen, Dies at 90
description: Starting in the Air Force in Israel and later moving to the United States, he set a record as the world’s most widely syndicated in his field.
content: Ranan Lurie, an Israeli war hero and world peacemaker who set records as the world’s most widely syndicated political cartoonist, died on Wednesday in Las Vegas. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Federal Prosecutors Open Criminal Inquiry of Wells Fargo’s Hiring Practices
description: Authorities are investigating whether the bank violated federal anti-discrimination laws by conducting sham interviews of minority candidates.
content: Federal prosecutors in New York have opened a criminal investigation into whether Wells Fargo violated federal laws by conducting sham interviews of minority and female job candidates, according to two people with knowledge of the inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: A Queer-Film Historian Discusses Movies That Provoke
description: Elizabeth Purchell, who has programmed a series on the documentaries of Rosa von Praunheim, sees Pride Month as a chance to discover, and uncover, the past.
content: Elizabeth Purchell isn’t afraid of “Transexual Menace,” even though she is a transgender woman and the film sounds like the kind of hateful propaganda you’d find for sale at a convention of conspiracy nuts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Ryan Kelley, a candidate for Michigan governor who was at the Capitol on Jan. 6, is arrested by the F.B.I.
description: Mr. Kelley faces several misdemeanor charges, including disorderly conduct, in connection with the attack on the Capitol.
content: Ryan Kelley, a Republican running for governor in Michigan who was at the Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack, was arrested at his home in Allendale, Mich., on Thursday morning, according to Mara R. Schneider, a special agent with the F.B.I.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Are Jan. 6 Hearings Flashy Enough for Prime Time? Late Night Isn’t Sure.
description: “Hanging over the hearings is one question that could define the future of our republic: Who cares?” Stephen Colbert said on Wednesday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Health officials again warn about possible effects on U.S. virus testing supply without more aid.
description: The officials described the consequences of repurposing Department of Health and Human Services funds meant for testing in order to pay for more vaccines and treatments.
content: Federal health officials on Thursday warned of potentially dire consequences to the U.S. coronavirus testing supply later this year if lawmakers do not replenish funding for the federal pandemic response, leaving the nation at risk of shortages and more dependent on foreign manufacturers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russia Opens 1,100 Cases Against Ukrainian P.O.W.s, Raising Fears of Show Trials
description: Announcing the invasion in February, Vladimir Putin said Ukrainians would be prosecuted for “blood crimes.” Moscow is now making good on that vow.
content: Russian investigators on Thursday said they had opened more than 1,100 cases into “crimes against peace” committed by the Ukrainian government, paving the way for what could turn into a mass show trial of hundreds of Ukrainian service members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley and Lauren Herstik
title: Bill Cosby’s Lawyer Accuses Judy Huth of Inventing Her Assault Account
description: During cross-examination of Ms. Huth, who has sued Mr. Cosby on grounds of sexual assault, the entertainer’s lawyer suggested she has lied about their encounter so she could file a lawsuit.
content: In withering cross-examination, Bill Cosby’s lawyer on Wednesday hammered Judy Huth on the question of why it had taken her decades to accuse the entertainer of sexually assaulting her at the Playboy Mansion in Los Angeles in 1975.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: Can Your Diet Really Affect Your Skin Cancer Risk?
description: A new study found that older adults who ate more fish were more likely to develop melanoma, but experts urged caution when interpreting the findings.
content: A large study published Wednesday found a surprising link between fish consumption and developing melanoma, the most serious type of skin cancer. But while the finding raises questions about possible links between diet and melanoma, the study’s lead author and other experts cautioned that it’s not a reason to avoid eating fish. It also doesn’t change the most important advice for reducing melanoma risk: Limit your exposure to UV rays from the sun or tanning beds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Prevost and Anne Mancuso
title: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and Westchester
description: This week’s available properties are a five-bedroom home in Fairfield, Conn., and a five-bedroom house in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘I’m Charlie Walker’ Review: More Wink Than Wallop
description: The actor Mike Colter imbues Charlie with cool savvy in this movie about a Black trucker in the ’70s who goes up against the white establishment.
content: In January 1971, two tankers collided in the waters beneath the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco, leaking 800,000 gallons of oil. The disaster is remembered for having spurred an environmental movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Louise Snyder
title: We Need Hope to Combat Violence. That Won’t Arrive Without Action.
description: To adequately address violence, we need to take stock of everything at once.
content: What might have stopped the gunman from killing 21 people in Uvalde, Texas? In the aftermath of the shootings, familiar details emerged. We know he fought with his mother. We know he has been accused of posting footage of him seriously abusing one or more cats online. We know he shot his grandmother, who worked at Robb Elementary. We know he harassed girls on social media and when one of those girls reported him to a social media app, nothing was done. And most critically, we know he bought a weapon of war around his 18th birthday from a company that offered buy-now-pay-later-style financing. The process for buying the gun was little more onerous than that for purchasing Sudafed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samanth Subramanian
title: A Radical Collective Takes Over One of the World’s Biggest Art Shows
description: Ruangrupa, an Indonesian group of collaborators, turns social experiences into art. How will they leave their mark on Documenta, which unfolds over 100 days.
content: For four out of every five years, Kassel is a relatively humdrum town. Its population of 217,796 inhabits a central German valley, hundreds of miles from Berlin or Munich. Its parks and palaces are Teutonic-prim. People eat their lunchtime kebabs on a plaza opposite the squat, sober Fridericianum, one of Europe’s oldest public art museum. The local football team, KSV Hessen Kassel, languishes in the fourth tier of the German league. But on the half-decade, when Kassel hosts Documenta, arguably the world’s largest exhibition of contemporary art, nearly a million visitors pour in over 100 summer days. The Fridericianum is the nucleus, but Documenta annexes the entire town — shops, gardens, warehouses, streets — leaving relics behind. A wanderer may be art-struck without warning. Once, walking by the Fulda River, I encountered a Claes Oldenburg sculpture, from a Documenta in 1982: a tremendous blue pickax planted bit-first into the soil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon, Jin Yu Young and Tiffany May
title: Fire Kills at Least 7 in South Korea; Arson Is Suspected
description: A man in his 50s was suspected of setting off the explosion that started the blaze at a law office in the city of Daegu, the police said. He is believed to have died in the fire.
content: SEOUL — Seven people were found dead and 48 others injured after an explosion set off by a spray of gasoline ignited a fire on Thursday at a law office in the southern city of Daegu, South Korea, according to the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Friday Briefing: A Crucial Moment in the Ukraine War
description: Plus the U.S. begins Jan. 6 hearings and Chinese pilots provoke U.S. allies.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky described the battle for Sievierodonetsk as a crucial moment in what is increasingly a war of attrition in eastern Ukraine. “The fate of our Donbas is being decided there,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Allows Undated Ballots in Pennsylvania Election
description: A state law required mailed ballots to be accompanied by a signed and dated declaration, but a federal appeals court ruled that undated declarations sufficed.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court said on Thursday that election officials in Pennsylvania may count mailed ballots accompanied by voters’ declarations that were signed but not dated. The court’s order came in a tight race for a seat on a state court, but it is likely to affect other contests in the state as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Justice Dept. Is Investigating Louisiana Police Over Accusations of Abuse
description: Similar investigations are underway into the Minneapolis Police Department in connection with the killing of George Floyd and the Louisville Police Department’s actions leading up to the shooting of Breonna Taylor.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Thursday opened an investigation into the Louisiana State Police over accusations that officers had engaged in abusive and discriminatory behavior, including the fatal beating of a Black motorist three years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Employee Fatally Shoots 3 at Maryland Manufacturing Plant, Officials Say
description: The suspect fled and was caught after exchanging gunfire with a Maryland State Police trooper, the authorities said. Both were injured.
content: An employee opened fire at manufacturing plant in Maryland on Thursday afternoon, killing three co-workers and critically injuring another before he was shot by a state trooper in an exchange of gunfire that left both wounded, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Stephanie Murphy: Her roots in Vietnam fuel a concern for democracy.
description: Her family’s escape from a war-torn Vietnam to the United States is part of what has shaped Ms. Murphy’s work on the select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
content: In spring 2002, Representative Stephanie Murphy, a Florida Democrat who was born in Vietnam, returned to the country for the first time as an adult with her father, as local elections were underway. She was shocked by the propaganda, as well as her relatives’ frank acknowledgment that their votes would not make a difference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Iran Begins to Dismantle Nuclear Program Cameras After Western Criticism
description: At a moment when experts say Iran is, again, on the verge of possessing enough fuel for a bomb, the dismantling of U.N. cameras was a sign of worsening prospects for the 2015 deal.
content: Iran began dismantling the U.N. monitoring system of its nuclear program this week, partly blinding nuclear inspectors in apparent retaliation for a resolution condemning its lack of cooperation with international inspectors, just at a moment when Tehran is again on the verge of possessing enough fuel for a bomb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anastasia Edel
title: The Door Between Russia and America Is Slamming Shut
description: The post-totalitarian dream of a peaceful, friendly future is over.
content: The war in Ukraine is a never-ending catastrophe. Russian forces, concentrated in the east, continue to inflict terrible damage on Ukrainian soldiers and civilians alike. Countless lives have been lost and upended. Once again, the world must confront the possibility of nuclear war and grapple with a compounding refugee and cost of living crisis. This isn’t the “end of history” that we hoped for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: A War Correspondent’s View
description: We talk to Carlotta Gall about the brutal fight in the east.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden and Bolsonaro of Brazil meet for the first time.
description: President Jair Bolsonaro addressed concerns about Brazil’s upcoming election, saying he came to power democratically and would leave office the same way.
content: President Biden met for the first time on Thursday with President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil, the leader of the second-largest country in the Western Hemisphere, in a face-to-face discussion that was one of the most anticipated of the ninth Summit of the Americas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: A Full Return to the Office? Does ‘Never’ Work for You?
description: Employer plans have played out like a game of chicken. Now workers are rebelling outright, and executives are trying everything to make the office worth it.
content: What Barrett Kime’s boss said on the recent video call was straightforward. Could members of his team at NBCUniversal show up on the few days a week that they were actually expected to be in the office?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller and Carl Zimmer
title: Mysteries Linger About Covid’s Origins, W.H.O. Report Says
description: “The lack of political cooperation from China continues to stifle any meaningful progress,” one expert said.
content: In its first report, a team of international scientists assembled by the World Health Organization to advise on the origins of the coronavirus said on Thursday that bats likely carried an ancestor of the coronavirus that may have then spilled over into a mammal sold at a wildlife market. But the team said that more Chinese data was needed to study how the virus spread to people, including the possibility that a lab leak played a role.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurel Graeber
title: Viewing the Civil Rights Movement Through Children’s Books
description: “Picture the Dream,” on display at the New-York Historical Society, shows that children, far from being mere witnesses to the civil rights movement, have played central roles in it.
content: In a verdant rural setting, a weathered gray fence separates two girls, one Black, one white. The Black child extends her hand as the white girl, already straddling the fence’s top rail, reaches down. Although they barely grasp each other’s fingers, a viewer can sense their curiosity, their anticipation, their desire to surmount this barrier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Berry
title: Nicole McLaughlin’s Designs Are No Joke
description: Her tongue-in-cheek approach to sustainable fashion sends a serious message: The only way to combat overconsumption is to produce less and repurpose more.
content: Nicole McLaughlin, a conceptual artist focused on sustainability, loves coming up with names for her creations. A beanie made from jeans is a “jeanie.” Shoes constructed from sushi are “shoeshi.” A bra whose cups are two bagels, a “bragel.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Ingram Marshall, Minimalist Composer of Mystical Sounds, Dies at 80
description: An influential figure in American experimental music, he was part of a group of composers who stripped music down to basic elements and used digital sounds.
content: Ingram Marshall, a minimalist composer known for the mystery and melancholy of his works, which featured sounds as disparate as San Francisco fog horns and Balinese bamboo flutes, died on May 31 in New Haven, Conn. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Back to the Office? Does ‘Never’ Work for You?
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 9, 2022.
content: “It’s almost like a meme now of the 2018 office — ‘Hey we have bagels and snacks and Ping-Pong tables.’ That’s not a trade-off for a commute.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: ‘Trump Was at the Center’: Jan. 6 Hearing Lays Out Case in Vivid Detail
description: The House panel investigating the attack led its public sessions with video testimony from people close to the former president about his actions before and during the riot.
content: WASHINGTON — The House Select Committee to Investigate the Jan. 6 Attack on the United States Capitol opened a landmark set of hearings on Thursday by showing video of aide after aide to former President Donald J. Trump testifying that his claims of a stolen election were false, as the panel laid out in meticulous detail the extent of the former president’s efforts to keep himself in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris, Elyssa Dudley, Hans Buetow, Sara Sarasohn, Sasha Weiss, Wendy Dorr, Marion Lozano and Aaron Richter
title: How a Highway Divided a Community in Philadelphia
description: On a personal episode of “Still Processing,” Wesley Morris revisits a highway that he walked across as a kid. He never knew how deeply it had transformed the neighborhood it ran through.
content: If given the choice to drive or walk, Wesley Morris, Times critic and co-host of “Still Processing,” will always choose to walk. He grew up in Philadelphia, but he resisted getting his driver’s license until the age of 32.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Reporter Felicia Sonmez Is Fired by The Washington Post
description: Ms. Sonmez, a national political reporter, has been at the center of a debate over The Post’s social media policies.
content: Felicia Sonmez, a reporter for The Washington Post who in recent days has been at the center of a debate over the organization’s social media policies and the culture of the newsroom, was fired on Thursday, according to three people with knowledge of the matter who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss personnel matters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Bruised, Battered and Thriving, the Mets Keep Dodging Disaster
description: Riddled with injuries — Pete Alonso’s is only the latest — the Mets still have the N.L.’s best record. They will face a spiraling Angels team that has been their polar opposite.
content: SAN DIEGO — The Mets were leading the majors in an assortment of categories through Wednesday, including runs scored (299), hits (525), on-base percentage (.334) and batting average (.263).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Place for a Hammer and Anvil
description: Dan Ziring makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — This may not be important to anyone besides me — and possibly my mother — but this column marks my 4,000th byline for The New York Times. That amounts to more than two million words, most of which I successfully got in the right order, and that is absolutely unfathomable to me to contemplate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: White House Outlines Coronavirus Vaccine Plan for Children Under 5
description: Vaccine deliveries to U.S. states are contingent on the Food and Drug Administration authorizing pediatric doses, a step that could occur as soon as next week.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House on Thursday outlined the early stages of its plan for making coronavirus vaccines available this month to roughly 18 million children younger than 5, should the doses be cleared by federal regulators for the last group of Americans yet to be eligible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: How to Cook (or Not Cook) an Artichoke
description: You can roast, steam, boil and fry this delicious vegetable, or even eat it raw.
content: My favorite, no-nonsense way to cook a globe artichoke at home is whole and steamed, or boiled. When they’re cool enough to touch, I pull the leaves away one by one and dip them into seasoned butter, or mayonnaise or some kind of lemony vinaigrette, and scrape the tiny bits of meat off with my teeth, until I get down to the choke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Logan Ury Says You’re Dating All Wrong
description: From her Oakland commune, a dating coach has made a big business out of her data-driven approach to modern romance.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — In the backyard of a luxury commune, slouched on the stones between a wood-barrel sauna and a cobalt blue Ping-Pong table, Logan Ury flicked fragments of acorns off her dress while the woman across from her recited her attachment style. A hot tub burbled in the background, where a string of fairy lights drooped between trees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: House Passes Red-Flag Bill as Senate Talks on Gun Violence Continue
description: The legislation stands little chance of enactment in its current form, but the idea of incentivizing states to allow guns to be taken from dangerous people is in play in bipartisan Senate talks.
content: WASHINGTON — The House on Thursday voted nearly along party lines to pass legislation that would allow guns to be temporarily confiscated from people deemed by a federal court to be dangerous, acting a day after it passed a sweeping measure to bar the sale of semiautomatic weapons to people under the age of 21 and ban the sale of large-capacity magazines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘First Person'
title: Abortion Didn’t Feel Like an Option. Neither Did Motherhood.
description: At 19, Merritt Tierce found herself unexpectedly pregnant and facing what felt like an impossible choice.
content: If the Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade in the coming weeks, tens of millions of women will find themselves living in states where abortion is outlawed in almost all cases. And for some women, that will mean having children — without actually wanting them — because they are left with no choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: A Plea From German Brewers: Bring Back Your Empties
description: A nation of beer lovers is facing a shortage of bottles, partly because of the war in Ukraine. Breweries are looking to drinkers for a rescue.
content: Stefan Fritsche, who runs a centuries-old German brewery in Neuzelle, near the Polish border, has seen his natural gas bill jump a startling 400 percent over the past year. His electricity bill has increased 300 percent. And he’s paying more for barley than ever before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Russia cements its grip on southern Ukraine.
content: Russia is cementing its grip on southern Ukraine, extending infrastructure that could help it claim permanent dominion over the region. The repair work would allow Moscow to fortify a “land bridge” between Russia and Crimea and build on efforts to claim control through the introduction of Russian currency and the appointment of proxy officials. Follow the latest updates from the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA Plans to Join U.F.O. Research Efforts
description: The truth is out there, and now America’s space agency will add its resources to the study of unidentified aerial phenomena.
content: U.F.O.s almost certainly are not alien visitors buzzing Earth’s skies, but NASA is nonetheless financing a study that will look at unexplained sightings with an open mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Duro Olowu Excavates Pattern at the Cooper Hewitt
description: The Nigerian-born British fashion designer examines the many ways and meanings of pattern in everything from wallpaper to ceremonial hats.
content: Good things almost always happen when museums invite outsiders to organize exhibitions from their permanent collections. This has certainly been true with the annual “Selects” exhibition at the Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum. Recent guest curators in the series, now in its 20th iteration, have included the architect David Adjaye, the artist Maira Kalman and the musician Esperanza Spalding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Dmitry Kovtun, Accused Killer of Russian Dissident, Dies at 56
description: He and another ex-spy were found by British authorities to have served polonium-laced tea in London to an intelligence agent who had defected.
content: Dmitry Kovtun, a former Russian intelligence agent accused of fatally poisoning a fellow ex-spy with green tea laced with radioactive polonium in the bar of a luxury London hotel, died on Saturday in a hospital in Moscow. He was 56.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Tahara’ Review: Hierarchy at a Hebrew-School Funeral
description: Rachel Sennott and Madeline Grey DeFreece star in a canny portrait of teenage insensitivity and sexuality amid a tragedy.
content: The Hebrew-school comedy “Tahara” mimics the zinging pleasure of overhearing teenagers chatter as they walk home from school: It’s gossipy, delicious and a tad cruel. The film eavesdrops on a group of teenage students during a critical day in their lives, when a classmate’s funeral has prompted them to wrestle with social status and school personas. Their dialogue crackles with vocal fry and viciousness as they reckon, maybe for the first time, with the consequences of school hierarchies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Putin the Great? Russia’s President Likens Himself to Famous Czar.
description: Vladimir Putin likened his goals in Ukraine to the conquests of Peter the Great.
content: Among President Vladimir V. Putin’s motives for invading Ukraine, his view of himself as being on a historic mission to rebuild the Russian Empire has always loomed large. On Thursday, Mr. Putin went further, comparing himself directly to Peter the Great.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Emma Bubola
title: Tourist Damages Rome’s Spanish Steps by Pushing a Scooter Down Them
description: An American woman and her companion caused $27,000 in damage to the landmark, officials said. They were fined and have been barred from the site for six months.
content: In the past 300 years, the Spanish Steps in Rome have been descended by artists, poets and lovers. They have provided a sweeping backdrop for fashion shows and selfies, and have featured in dozens of films, including “Roman Holiday,” from 1953, starring Audrey Hepburn and Gregory Peck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.J. Goldmann
title: A Homecoming, of Sorts, for Viennese Plays
description: Two recent British dramas with Austrian roots made it to Vienna this season: “Leopoldstadt,” by Tom Stoppard, and Robert Icke’s “The Doctor.”
content: VIENNA — Leopoldstadt is the name of a central Viennese district with a large Jewish population. It is also the title of Tom Stoppard’s 2020 Olivier Award-winning play, which opened on the West End shortly before the start of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: ATP Approves Raft of Changes to Share Tennis’s Wealth
description: The package includes profit-sharing between tournaments and players and the expansion of Masters 1000 tournaments in an effort to narrow the gap between them and the Grand Slams.
content: PARIS — The ATP, which runs the men’s professional tennis tour, has approved a large package of changes that include profit-sharing between tournaments and players and making five more of the tour’s top-line Masters 1000 events bigger and longer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Stella Abrera to Run the ABT Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis School for a Year
description: Abrera, a former principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, has been named acting director of the school.
content: Stella Abrera, a former principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, has been named acting artistic director of the ABT Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis School, the company announced on Thursday. Abrera will oversee all artistic aspects of the school’s children’s division, pre-professional division and national training curriculum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Inside Playful Photo Shoots
description: Three New York Times Magazine photo editors share their tips for creative captures.
content: Outside a cabin in Los Angeles last spring, Amy Kellner, a senior photo editor for The New York Times Magazine, faced a conundrum. The prop stylist had ordered more than 100 wildflowers as well as proteas, tulips and artificial flowers so that the comedian Seth Rogen, the subject of a cover shoot, could lie down in them. But when the photographer, Chris Buck, took test shots from above, he realized that Mr. Rogen’s facial features would appear distorted from that angle. So Mr. Buck came up with a quick solution: String the blooms on chicken wire, held up by clamp stands — and ask a standing Rogen to stick his head through. “He was game,” Ms. Kellner said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Kevin Draper
title: Warner Bros. Discovery Picks Sports Chief to Navigate Streaming Era
description: The executive, Luis Silberwasser, will be responsible for crucial talks with the N.B.A. at a time when the value of live sports rights are soaring.
content: Warner Bros. Discovery, the media giant created by the fusion of the owners of HBO and “90 Day Fiancé,” said Thursday that it had picked an executive to manage its billions of dollars of sports rights, one of the cornerstones of the company. The company now has the rights to games from the National Basketball Association and the National Hockey League.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timo Andres
title: Ingram Marshall Built and Obscured Monoliths of Sound
description: The composer and pianist Timo Andres remembers his former teacher, who “gave the impression that all of music was at our feet.”
content: I first came to know the composer Ingram Marshall, who died on May 31 at 80, as a campus personality. Benevolent and slightly spectral, he’d glide into Yale’s music library, where I had a work-study job as an undergraduate student, and I’d help him find scores and recordings. I already knew a few of his pieces, and was a bit awe-struck chatting with their creator. His musical and real-life personalities seemed directly related: unhurried, easygoing, more likely to follow a train of thought than pursue a rigorous argument, but unafraid to let the conversation become serious or philosophical.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Stengel
title: Misdirection, Fake News and Lies: The Best Books to Read on Disinformation
description: The phenomenon has undermined our trust in electoral systems, in vaccines — and in what happened at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. Here are books on its history, techniques and effects.
content: False statements, misdirection, half-truths and outright lies: When promoted and repeated in the echo chambers of social media, they can shape attitudes, influence policy and erode democracy. As the psychologist Daniel Kahneman has said, you can make people believe in falsehood through repetition, “because familiarity is not easily distinguished from truth.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Chinese Pilots Sent a Message. American Allies Said They Went Too Far.
description: Australia and Canada said Chinese jets harassed their military planes, though Beijing says it was defending its security. A mishap over Pacific waters could have ominous repercussions.
content: HONG KONG — Chinese jets repeatedly buzzed a Canadian plane monitoring North Korea, sometimes coming so close that the pilots could see each other. Hundreds of miles to the south, a Chinese fighter plane sprayed metallic chaff in the path of an Australian surveillance craft, a maneuver that Australia called “very dangerous.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay, Jessica Testa and Vanessa Friedman
title: Fetish Fashion, the Writhe and Fall
description: Megan Thee Stallion, Bella Hadid and Chloë Sevigny appear in a viral video for Mugler. But who’s buying it?
content: On Wednesday, Mugler released a video for its spring 2022 collection, the final installment in a trilogy of high-octane, super-sexy fashion films directed by Torso Solutions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: With Lifeguards Scarce, It’s Beach Season That Needs Rescuing
description: Lifeguards are in short supply around the country this year because of low unemployment and Covid’s effects on training. Pools have been left closed and beaches unguarded.
content: MILWAUKEE — On the first week of June in Wisconsin, beachgoers on a neatly groomed Lake Michigan shore strolled past volleyball nets on rainbow-striped poles and a waterfront cafe menu offering bratwurst, quesadillas and mojitos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: ‘This Is Uncomfortable’: Saudi Arabia Upends Genteel World of Pro Golf
description: By promising top players multimillion-dollar paydays, the kingdom moved beyond investing in a sport and made a play to control one. Then the PGA Tour struck back.
content: ST. ALBANS, England — First, the Saudis signed up a handful of the best-known names in golf to headline their new global tour, tempting players like Phil Mickelson and a few other past champions with staggering paychecks. Then they lured even bigger stars, the kind whose talents could make the series a credible rival to pro golf’s existing gold standard, the PGA Tour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: New 42 Worker Files Bias Lawsuit Over Diversity Training
description: A white teaching artist at the theater organization says it discriminated against white people. The nonprofit declined to comment.
content: A contract worker at a nonprofit New York theater organization has filed a lawsuit saying that the institution’s diversity trainings were themselves discriminatory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: Lina Khan, a Big Tech Critic, Tries Answering Her Own Detractors
description: In an interview, the chair of the Federal Trade Commission laid out some of her plans now that she has a Democratic majority at the agency.
content: WASHINGTON — Nearly a year into her job as chair of the Federal Trade Commission, Lina Khan hasn’t quite made the splash that many expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: House Again Delays Bill Bolstering Security for Supreme Court Justices
description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi said a bill to extend protections to the justices’ families and court officers would come to a vote early next week, but Republicans accused her of playing politics.
content: WASHINGTON — House Democrats put off consideration of Senate-passed legislation to bolster protections for Supreme Court justices a day after a man armed with a pistol, a knife and other weapons was arrested near the Maryland home of Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Schmidt
title: Jump in Mortgage Rates Could Add $100,000 to Housing Costs
description: With interest rates at 5 percent, borrowers could pay thousands in extra costs over the lifetime of a 30-year home loan, a report shows.
content: The recent rise in U.S. mortgage rates could bump up the average mortgage payment by hundreds of dollars each month, potentially adding more than $100,000 in costs over the lifetime of a typical loan, a new study shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Rogers
title: More Than Fjords: A New Museum to Put Oslo on the Map
description: City administrators hope Norway’s new National Museum will help Oslo, and the rest of the country, step out of its Scandinavian neighbors’ shadows.
content: OSLO — For decades, Oslo lived in the shadow of Scandinavia’s two other capitals, Stockholm and Copenhagen. The Norwegian city, alongside a picturesque fjord dotted with rugged islands, has often been derided as sleepy and overpriced, or as a mere stopping-off point for tourists heading into the Norwegian mountains or boarding a cruise along the coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: Witching Up ‘Giselle.’ (The Horror, oh the Horror.)
description: English National Ballet brings Akram Khan’s “Giselle” to the Brooklyn Academy of Music, a production that prizes style over substance.
content: Akram Khan’s “Giselle” isn’t so much a remake of a treasured ballet as it is an impressionistic proposition: Is there a way that “Giselle” could be sensed or felt instead of seen or heard? Certainly, it’s dark. You start to think that its lighting designer, Mark Henderson, is sentimental about caves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and John Koblin
title: Disney fires Peter Rice, its top TV content executive.
description: Some in the entertainment business had once seen him as a possible candidate to succeed Bob Chapek as Disney’s chief executive.
content: The Walt Disney Company has abruptly fired Peter Rice, its most senior television content executive, citing an ill fit with Disney’s corporate culture, according to three people briefed on the matter who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss confidential information.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth G. Dunn and Gabby Jones
title: How ‘Fairy Tale’ Farms Are Ruining Hudson Valley Agriculture
description: Farmers are losing properties to wealthy buyers from the city, while leasing land from the new owners can feel like a “modern-day feudal system.”
content: As first-time livestock farmers, Maddie Morley and Benjamin Roberts had beaten the odds in a profession that is often expensive and grueling for those starting out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Review: In ‘Snow in Midsummer,’ It’s Not Just the Forecast That’s Amiss
description: Adapted from a 13th-century drama, Frances Ya-Chu Cowhig’s play is part ghost story, murder mystery and family melodrama.
content: In the Chinese town of New Harmony, a three-year drought has ravaged the landscape. The lake has evaporated. Ash falls from the sky. Nothing grows. While some characters blame global warming, these natural disasters have a supernatural explanation. A young widow has been executed for a crime she did not commit. Before she dies, she curses New Harmony: Until she is avenged and buried, the town will suffer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Deshaun Watson’s Case Tests the N.F.L.’s Resolve, and Its Values
description: Given the volume and seriousness of the allegations against the Cleveland Browns quarterback, our columnist wonders if an N.F.L. suspension is enough of a punishment.
content: Twenty-two accusers. No, this just in, make that 23. Wait, now it’s 24.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iliana Rocha and Victoria Chang
title: Poem: The Many Deaths of Inocencio Rodriguez
description: This poem is a meditation on memory’s playback loop, as well as both the specific and general violence against immigrants and people of color.
content: This poem tells the story of Inocencio Rodriguez, the author’s grandfather, who was murdered in 1971. It’s a meditation on memory’s playback loop, as well as both the specific and general violence against immigrants and people of color. Rocha’s images are askew and arresting — the “street hangs from the sky” and summer has dark hair that is “lazily in a braid” — before the poem shifts to a home scene that propels us to a tragic ending and ruminates on details leading to Rodriguez’s murder. Poem Selected by Victoria Chang
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘Ninja Badass’ Review: Kill Bad Guys, Save Hot Babes, Look Silly
description: Ryan Harrison, an auteur of the gross, includes sight gags like puppies in blenders in this tedious action comedy.
content: “Ninja Badass,” a crude, abrasive action-comedy about an Indiana hillbilly training to become a superpowered martial artist, is the product of one peculiar mind. Ryan Harrison is the writer, director, co-producer, editor and star of “Ninja Badass”; he even created its cheap but plentiful visual effects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Asteroid Samples May ‘Rewrite the Chemistry of the Solar System’
description: The flecks of rock were brought back to Earth by the Japanese space mission Hayabusa2 in December 2020.
content: One-fifth of an ounce of dark specks brought to Earth from an asteroid by a Japanese spacecraft are some of the most pristine bits of a baby solar system ever studied, scientists announced on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Tough, Physical Play Giving Boston a Finals Edge on Golden State
description: The Celtics lead the N.B.A. finals, two games to one, in a series that has been defined by size and rebounds more than finesse and flash.
content: BOSTON — After Game 3 of the N.B.A. finals, Boston Celtics center Robert Williams attended his postgame news conference dressed in a T-shirt with the face of the bruising, Hall of Fame player Dennis Rodman printed on it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘1982’ Review: When War Canceled School
description: This film from the director Oualid Mouaness is inspired by his memories of being a child during the Israeli invasion of Lebanon that year.
content: “1982,” the first feature from Oualid Mouaness, is inspired by the director’s memories of having his classroom life suddenly interrupted by the Israeli invasion of Lebanon that year. The film takes place at a school in East Beirut over a single day that begins quietly enough, although the first sound we hear is of rumbling planes. A fifth-grader, Wissam (Mohamad Dalli), slips an anonymous love note into the locker of Joanna (Gia Madi), a girl he likes from West Beirut, the mainly Muslim half of the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Jonathan Martin
title: Liz Cheney Takes On Trump, and Her Own Party
description: “There will come a day when President Trump is gone,” the Wyoming Republican warned members of her party at the Jan. 6 hearing. “But your dishonor will remain.”
content: WASHINGTON — Representative Liz Cheney, Republican of Wyoming, had just matter-of-factly rattled off a string of damning revelations illustrating how former President Trump had stoked the mob who attacked the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, when she paused to address the members of her own party who she said were “defending the indefensible.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: With Elon Musk, the Drama Is the Point
description: Will he buy Twitter? Nobody knows — but what does it matter, as long as you keep paying attention?
content: Previously on “Elon,” our man rushed into a $44 billion deal to buy Twitter just before the bottom fell out of tech stocks, including his own. Not the best timing, but fret not, for Elon’s always got an out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Janet Yellen says the U.S. is likely to avoid a recession.
description: While the Treasury secretary predicted rising gas prices, she said strong employment and household finances would avert an economic downturn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Ariana DeBose on Hosting the Tonys: ‘Whatever We Do Is Going to Be Fun’
description: The Broadway ensemble member turned Oscar winner vows that the ceremony will celebrate the often unsung actors who have stepped in so often during the pandemic.
content: A decade ago, Ariana DeBose made her Broadway debut as an understudy in the musical adaptation of “Bring It On.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: U.S. Accelerated Expulsions of Haitian Migrants in May
description: The uptick has rekindled criticism that the Biden administration treats Black migrants differently than others, an allegation it denies.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration expelled nearly 4,000 Haitians on 36 deportation flights in May — a significant increase over the previous three months — after renegotiating agreements with the island nation, which has been crippled by gang violence and an expanding humanitarian crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Chris Blackwell Is Music’s Quietest ‘Record Man.’ His Artists Speak Loudly.
description: In a new memoir, the 84-year-old founder of Island Records reflects on helping bring the music of Bob Marley, U2 and Grace Jones to the world.
content: Most music industry memoirs are front-loaded with celebrity name-dropping. “The Islander: My Life in Music and Beyond” by Chris Blackwell, the founder of Island Records — whose success with Bob Marley, U2, Steve Winwood and Grace Jones would offer plenty to boast about — instead opens with a parable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: David Axelrod, Sarah Longwell and Preet Bharara on What to Look For in the Jan. 6 Hearings
description: Our panelists discuss how televising the House committee sessions could shape the long-haul defense of democracy.
content: The House’s Jan. 6 committee is going prime-time. On Thursday, its members, with Representative Liz Cheney, Republican of Wyoming, serving as vice chair, will present findings in hearings televised throughout June on all major networks (except Fox News). But will Americans watch? Or care?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Read an excerpt from the committee chairman’s opening statement.
description: “We can’t sweep what happened under the rug,” Representative Bennie Thompson of Mississippi is expected to say in his opening statement.
content: This evening, the opening statement of Representative Bennie Thompson of Mississippi, the chairman of the House committee investigating the Capitol riot, will include the following excerpt:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israeli Prime Minister Visits an Arab Ally Amid Tensions With Iran
description: The trip by Naftali Bennett, the Israeli leader, burnishes his foreign policy credentials and provides some distraction from his domestic political troubles.
content: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Naftali Bennett of Israel made a snap trip to the United Arab Emirates on Thursday, the latest display of the strengthening alliance between the two countries and their united front against Iran amid rising tensions over Tehran’s nuclear ambitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: In ‘For All Mankind,’ the Future Is in the Past
description: Apple TV+’s refreshingly retro space thriller reverse-engineers history to find an interplanetary path not taken. (Next stop, Mars!)
content: Apropos of its title, “For All Mankind” begins with one small step, in a different direction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes for Sale in New York City
description: This week’s available properties are in Chelsea, Cobble Hill and Midtown.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Wilson
title: ‘The Lost Girls’ Review: Wendy’s Telling of Peter Pan
description: In her second feature film, the director Livia De Paolis awkwardly tries to comment on the gender dynamics in J.M Barrie’s classic.
content: Peter Pan might persist as a symbol of whimsy, but never growing up also has a dark side. In her latest film, “The Lost Girls,” based on the novel of the same name by Laurie Fox, the Italian writer and director Livia De Paolis depicts generations of women haunted by Never Never Land. At least, she tries to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Summit of the Americas Kicks Off in Los Angeles
description: President Biden, Vice President Kamala Harris and dozens of world leaders arrive in Los Angeles for the event.
content: Los Angeles has transformed into a major geopolitical stage this week as President Biden and dozens of other world leaders convene here for the ninth Summit of the Americas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Small Town Wisconsin’ Review: A Father-Son Trip Goes Awry
description: A major-league farewell journey turns into an adventure for this dad who is losing shared custody.
content: Taking advantage of a shared custody arrangement that is soon to be justifiably voided, a divorced father, Wayne (David Sullivan), entertains his young son, Tyler (Cooper J. Friedman), in an unorthodox way. Wayne takes Tyler to the house in which Wayne grew up (they enter the property through a hole in a chain-link fence; nearby hangs a sign reading “Bank Owned”) and imitates the harangues his own abusive, alcoholic father delivered at the ancestral dinner table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Paladino Draws Backlash for Calling Hitler ‘the Kind of Leader We Need’
description: Carl Paladino, a Republican House candidate from New York, has been endorsed by Representative Elise Stefanik, a member of party leadership.
content: Carl P. Paladino, a Republican running for a House seat in Western New York, praised Adolf Hitler last year for inspiring his followers, describing the fascist dictator as “the kind of leader we need today.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Leader of Mexican Church Is Sentenced to 16 Years for Sex Crimes
description: Naasón Joaquín García, head of the church La Luz del Mundo, pleaded guilty in Los Angeles to sexually abusing three minors.
content: LOS ANGELES — The leader of La Luz del Mundo, a Mexico-based church that claims to have more than one million followers worldwide, was sentenced on Wednesday to more than 16 years in prison for sexually abusing three minors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marina Harss
title: The Everyday Avant-Gardist: Paul Taylor’s First Principles
description: A program of early works at the Joyce Theater shows a different, more experimental side of the choreographer.
content: The budding choreographer Paul Taylor, who would one day become a giant of American modern dance, put on a full evening of original works in October 1957. He was 27, and a dancer in Martha Graham’s company. The evening, “Seven New Dances,” was a series of seven short movement experiments. Whether they could really be described as dances was not immediately clear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: The U.S. and Latin American countries will commit to receive more migrants.
description: A joint declaration is expected to be issued Friday meant to address surging migration rates that have affected nations throughout the region.
content: LOS ANGELES — The United States and Latin American countries on Friday plan to issue a joint declaration at the Americas summit, committing nations across the region to receive migrants and provide avenues for them to secure humanitarian protection and earn a living, according to U.S. officials who publicly spoke of the plans Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Boston Celtics Withstand Stephen Curry for Game 3 Win in N.B.A. Finals
description: Golden State’s Curry had 31 points, including six 3-pointers, but Jaylen Brown, Marcus Smart and Jayson Tatum had big games of their own for Boston.
content: BOSTON — It was only the second quarter, but the Celtics’ Jayson Tatum seemed determined to build on a theme as he eyed an opportunity on Wednesday night. He took a hard dribble at Stephen Curry, spun to his right and drove straight into the lane before depositing a layup over his smaller defender.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: You Won’t Use That Cool Feature
description: So why do all these settings even exist?
content: It happens like clockwork. Companies, including Apple this week, introduce new options to make their gadgets feel new and improved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: These G.O.P. Lawmakers Went to D.C. on Jan. 6. Here’s Where They Are Now.
description: Twenty-one state legislators joined the crowds in Washington as they sought to overturn the 2020 election. For some, it was a ticket to grass-roots stardom on the right. For others, it was a political dead end.
content: Much of the news coverage of Donald Trump’s attempt to overturn the 2020 election has rightly focused on the machinations in and around the White House. If you haven’t yet, read The New York Times’s big package today pulling together the definitive timeline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Vander Ploeg and Mitch Smith
title: Michigan Police Officer Charged With Murder After Killing Black Motorist
description: Patrick Lyoya was fatally shot by a white Grand Rapids officer during a traffic stop, renewing a national debate about police conduct and use of force.
content: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — The video shocked residents: A police officer wrestling on the ground with a Black man who had fled from a traffic stop, then pulling out a gun and firing a single round into the back of the man’s head, killing him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: The Precarious Art of Cecilia Vicuña
description: Chilean-born, New York-based, she emerges at the Guggenheim after years under the art-market radar with just the right scrappy feel.
content: After the spectacle of high-end hoarding that was this spring’s art fair and auction season, it’s refreshing to find a career survey at the Guggenheim Museum of an artist who has always regarded much of her work as disposable — she refers to one series of sculptures as “basuritas” (little garbages) — and has used it to promote the ideal of a socially and environmentally sustainable world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Can I Tell My Parents That Their Estate Plan Hurts My Feelings?
description: A reader is upset that her brother and each of his children will inherit the same amount as she does.
content: My brother and I are both around 50 years old. I’m single, and he’s married with three kids approaching college age. Our parents are in their 70s. Over dinner, they announced their estate plan: Instead of splitting everything in half between my brother and me, as I expected them to, they told us they are dividing their estate into fifths: one-fifth for me, one-fifth for my brother and one-fifth for each of his kids. I didn’t say anything, but this seems really unfair to me. Now, add the fact that I’m the only one who lives near my parents, and when they need help, they call me. Should I say something?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Administration to Set Rules of the Road for Charging Electric Vehicles
description: Proposed regulations would require charging stations built with federal dollars to be located no more than 50 miles apart.
content: WASHINGTON — Electric vehicle charging stations built with federal dollars should be positioned along Interstates every 50 miles, be able to recharge cars quickly and be located no more than a mile from a major highway, according to new rules proposed by the Biden administration on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Zoe Lofgren: An impeachment veteran brings her expertise to the inquiry.
description: A close ally of Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California, Ms. Lofgren, first elected to Congress in 1994, is one of four lawyers on the committee.
content: Representative Zoe Lofgren, Democrat of California, has described the attack on the Capitol and the events leading up to it as “more serious than the threat that was posed by Watergate to our country.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norman Eisen and E. Danya Perry
title: The Jan. 6 Hearings Can Prove Trump’s Big Lie Is Still a Threat
description: The success of the committee rests on whether it can build a partnership with American voters to see the truth of what happened and what is still happening.
content: The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol begins its hearings tonight for the American public, hoping to shine a spotlight on the discoveries from its months of painstaking inquiry. How should we measure success?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Mooj Zadie, Diana Nguyen, Michael Simon Johnson, Rachel Quester, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: The Proud Boys’ Path to Jan. 6
description: How an informal drinking club for men graduated into a right-wing group now charged with sedition.
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: National Parks Begin Long Goodbye to Plastic Water Bottles
description: An Interior Department order will end the sale of single-use plastic products at national parks and on other public lands in the United States by 2032.
content: Sales of plastic water bottles and other single-use plastic products will be phased out at national parks and on public lands in the United States over the next decade, the Interior Department said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: At Summit of Americas, Biden Pledges U.S. Help on Latin American Problems
description: Opening the three-day summit, the president delivered a version of his domestic economic pitch, urging governments to invest in workers and the middle class.
content: LOS ANGELES — President Biden opened the three-day Summit of the Americas on Wednesday by promising leaders from Latin America that the United States was committed to helping the region combat crime, corruption and its economic struggles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Aware of Injuries Inside, Uvalde Police Waited to Confront Gunman
description: More than a dozen students remained alive for over an hour before officers entered their classrooms. The commander feared a risk to officers’ lives, new documents show.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — Heavily armed officers delayed confronting a gunman in Uvalde, Texas, for more than an hour even though supervisors at the scene had been told that some trapped with him in two elementary school classrooms needed medical treatment, a new review of video footage and other investigative material shows. Instead, the documents show, they waited for protective equipment to lower the risk to law enforcement officers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Sean Thackrey, Creator of Eccentric California Wines, Dies at 79
description: A polymath, he dismissed conventional wisdom about varietals, terroir and scientific management and won a cult following in the process.
content: Sean Thackrey, an autodidactic polymath who, in between collecting antiquarian books, running a San Francisco art gallery and learning five languages, developed a cult following as one of California’s most intriguingly eccentric winemakers, died on May 31 in Walnut Creek, Calif. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: An Exodus From the City’s Public Defense Offices
description: Hundreds of lawyers have left over the past year, saying they are undervalued and overworked.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at public defenders who are leaving their jobs, citing low pay. We’ll also look at one man’s quest for new ways to cultivate seaweed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Biden’s Choice to Run the A.T.F. Picks Up Support of 2 Key Democrats
description: The backing appears to pave the way for the nominee, Steven Dettelbach, to become the first permanent director of the agency responsible for enforcing gun laws in nearly a decade.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s nominee to run the embattled Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives appears to have secured the 50 votes needed to ensure his confirmation after two conservative Democrats came out in favor of his nomination on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: N.Y.C. is lifting a mask mandate for toddlers on Monday.
description: New York City is still strongly recommending that masks be worn indoors for people of all ages, however, as new, confirmed coronavirus cases still remain at a high level despite recent declines.
content: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City will end the mask mandate for 2- to 4-year-old children who attend day care and preschool on Monday, he said Thursday, because the city is past the peak of its latest wave of coronavirus cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: The Billionaires Behind a Push to Reinvigorate U.S. Chip-Making
description: A group that includes Eric Schmidt and Peter Thiel isn’t simply funding the effort itself: It wants American taxpayers to help foot the bill.
content: Amid the debate about how the United States can bring more manufacturing of semiconductors back to the country and worries it has become a national security concern, a surprising group of well-connected billionaires has quietly assembled to influence the way Washington approaches this thorny challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Republicans Try to Undercut Jan. 6 Committee With Inaccurate Claims
description: Before public hearings begin, Republican lawmakers sought to portray the panel as illegitimate.
content: Hours before the House committee investigating the Capitol riot opens its public hearings, Republican lawmakers sought to portray the panel as illegitimate. In a news conference, they denounced the committee’s formation, its work and Speaker Nancy Pelosi with inaccurate claims. Here’s a fact check.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Grachan Moncur III, Trombonist Whose Star Shone Briefly, Dies at 85
description: He mixed free jazz and post-bop in notable 1960s and ’70s recordings. But he withdrew from the jazz scene, in part because of a dispute over publishing rights.
content: Grachan Moncur III, a trombonist and composer who came to renown in the 1960s and early ’70s for his deft playing of a hybrid of post-bop and free jazz, but who later receded from the spotlight, died on June 3 — his 85th birthday — in a hospital in Newark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Casey Schwartz
title: A Daughter, Her Father and the Long-Gone Poet Who Brought Them Together
description: In her memoir “Also a Poet: Frank O’Hara, My Father, and Me,” Ada Calhoun set out to write a poet’s biography and found a connection to her father instead.
content: In the fall of 2018, the writer Ada Calhoun went into the basement of her parents’ apartment on St. Marks Place, in Manhattan’s East Village. She was looking for old toys to give her goddaughter. What she found instead — a cache of dusty cassette tapes — would become her next book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: PGA Tour Suspends Players Participating in Rival Golf Series
description: The PGA Tour commissioner said pros taking part in the new LIV Golf Series were now ineligible for his tour’s events, and he warned others thinking of joining that they would face the same discipline.
content: ST. ALBANS, England — It was only after they hit their first shots on Thursday that the professional golfers taking part in the new Saudi-financed LIV Golf Invitational Series would have learned how high the stakes they were playing for really were.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Liz Cheney Will Not Tolerate Trump’s Lies
description: At the risk of political suicide, the vice chair of the Jan. 6 committee will hold the former president to account.
content: I keep waiting for Liz Cheney to flinch.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Technically, summer doesn’t begin for another week and a half. But, really, what is time? If the N.H.L. can decide that ice hockey is still in season (go, Rangers!), then surely we book lovers can cheat a little in the other direction and declare an early start to summer reading. The important part of that equation isn’t summer, anyway; it’s reading. So dive right in.

title: ‘The Walk’ Review: Two Families So Far Apart
description: This sentimental drama about an upstanding cop caught up in the 1974 school desegregation conflict in Boston recycles tired white-savior clichés.
content: Set in South Boston in 1974, in the riotous aftermath of court-ordered school desegregation, Daniel Adams’s “The Walk” shows its hand early on. We first meet Billy (Justin Chatwin), a working-class Irish cop, as he lets a Black shoplifter off the hook and even pays for the man’s stolen baby formula. The perp responds incredulously with a comment that emerges as the film’s thematic refrain: “Damn, I guess there are some good white pigs left.”

title: From the South Side to the Loop, Chicago’s Innovative Spirit Thrives
description: Theater, art and music are flourishing, and on the culinary scene, a 13-course Filipino tasting menu and a sleek Black-owned winery in Bronzeville are just a few of the city’s new offerings.
content: Lacey Irby and her business partner, Ryan Brosseau, a chef, were planning to open a restaurant when the pandemic hit. It delayed them, but eventually, in early 2021, they opened Dear Margaret, a homey tribute to Mr. Brosseau’s Canadian grandmother in the Lakeview neighborhood, with takeout only, gradually adding patio dining and finally, last June, the snug dining room. It recently earned a Bib Gourmand award from Michelin — signaling quality and value — and reservations are scarce.

content: BRUSSELS — The researcher claims there has been an I.Q. decline in France linked to large-scale migration from North Africa. He has co-written a book about the global decline of intelligence, stating a relationship between ethnicity and cognitive abilities. And he argues that humans can be divided into subspecies, a cornerstone of white supremacist ideology.

content: Several blocks of Telegraph Avenue on the south side of the campus of the University of California, Berkeley, have been a contested space on and off for the past 60 years. In the 1960s, the street became the center of an anarchic West Coast counterculture of hippies, artists and dropouts once described as “the greatest freak show on earth.” In 1969, a group of radicals inspired by the nearby People’s Park fight created the Berkeley Liberation Program and sought to turn the stretch of Telegraph into a “strategic free territory for revolution.”

Does the product go over or under moisturizer? Is mineral sunscreen more effective (and why is it often chalky)? Why do some products leave a white cast on skin, and how can that be avoided?

title: ‘Lost Illusions’ Review: The Sweet Smell of Success
description: Xavier Giannoli’s headlong adaptation of a Balzac novel paints a timely picture of literary ambition and media corruption in 19th-century France.
content: A young person from the provinces sets out for the big city, seeking fortune and fame and finding temptation, corruption and ruin. It’s a story that never gets old — there’s usually plenty of lust, ambition and greed to keep the narrative engine humming — and variations pop up in the literature of nearly every nation and era. “Lost Illusions,” Honoré de Balzac’s novel of Parisian literary life, stands as a stellar example in its period and now, thanks to Xavier Giannoli’s invigorating screen adaptation, in ours as well.
